review_title: good organization that care for People

job_title: Bilingual Medical Case Manager in Denver, CO
pros: The pay is decent and pharmaceutical companies will pay for your lunch, if you're lucky enough to get the e-mail.
cons:
The medical insurance is a rip-off and will cost you more than going out of pocket in most cases, human resources is horrible and is not your friend at the Colorado Health Network, and *literally* all of upper management is terrible; absolute bottom of the barrel both professionally and as people. 

Apart from upper management, there is *constant* turn over, I'm talking entirely different teams of individuals every year because the upper management is so atrocious. You will be gaslighted at some point as an employee at the Colorado Health Network; so unless you're buddies with the CEO, expect to be treated like garbage and dispensable. The negative reviews are so on-point and an accurate look into the Colorado Health Network. Please read them and take them seriously. 

Working here was one of the most terrible and quite frankly, traumatizing, professional experiences I've had in my life. I've never been so gaslighted, disrespected, and mistreated as a professional working in human services. Despite what job postings may say, they do not value Harm Reduction nor do they value People Living With HIV unless, of course, they are wealthy donors of the organization. Please stay away if you value your sanity and self-respect. 

Upper management at the Colorado Health Network are the absolute worse, they are racist, misogynistic, patriarchal, sexist, and ableist. Lower management and employees are constantly replaced. They will sell the organization to you and make you believe that they believe in healthy equity and work to address structural bias and institutional racism but they are lying to you. Do not work here if you actually want to do some good in the world.

review_title: Corporate Social Work with Non-Profit Status
job_title: Client Services in Denver, CO
pros: Mission, Benefits, Co-workers, Client Relationships, Middle Managers
cons: The team of executive officers and directors fail their employees in multiple ways. They use passive-aggressive language in professional emails, blame shift, and gaslight middle managers and client-facing workers. They effectively built a labor hierarchy, that mirrors large corporations, in which client-facing employees' supervision, development, and worth go mostly overlooked. The team of executive officers and directors has a low tolerance for push-back, critique, and self-advocacy from subordinates. When any issue is addressed [from the "bottom-up"] the most common response is insecure hostility. This response supports an office culture that fosters a lack of boundaries, pettiness, and high turn-over. Lastly, the executive officers and directors need constant (re)education about issues of race and gender... it's one of the weakest "safe spaces" I've worked in.

review_title: Great on the surface, execution needs work
job_title: Program Manager in Denver, CO
pros: Comprehensive benefits package, generous PTO, relaxed work environment, great cause, interesting work with passionate employees
cons: Poor support of employees, no training or support given to managers, drama and pettiness, salary of management leaves quite a bit to be desired, lack of oversight and accountability for CEO, deeply rooted patriarchy, lack of processes for job duties and disciplinary action, irregular funding, in-fighting between executive level management that trickles down to all staff members, distrust between coordinator level staff and management team, inconsistent boundaries and rules

job_title: Client Services in Denver, CO
pros: Case Managers are not micro-managed, occasionally drug companies will come in and bring free lunch, relaxed dress code, on a major bus line
cons:
Management is awful.  They do not trust their employees with anything - not even tissues.  If you want a box of tissues you have to go to upstairs and talk to the them. One person stores them in his office.

They had a big "investigation" because two employees quit because of racism and discrimination within the organization - the "investigation" was "inconclusive".  They had a meeting with all of the staff (that was announced 24 hrs prior). Regarding discrimination. It was said that we were diverse "we have one of everything".  How can an organization thrive when a top official is racist?

If you are a woman or person of color, it is very hard to move up in the org and be heard.  If you are a cute, white male, you will do well in this company.

Turnover is high!

review_title: I loved the people and the work!
job_title: Public Health Intervention Coordinator in Denver, CO
pros: The people were the best, and I miss them everyday.  Not to mention, BEST BOSS EVER!  As another revue said, the overall environment is welcoming to all regardless of gender identity, sexual orientation, race or religious background.  You simply can't beat the people and culture here.  There are two other reviews that complain about a lack of diversity, but I don't know what they're expecting.  The CEO is Latino, there are LGBTQ people in all levels including management and my boss was a woman.
cons: The pay is tough for Denver.  It's pretty good for a non-profit, but with the sudden increase in the cost of living in Colorado, especially Denver, it's tough to make ends meet.

review_title: Great mission, terrible execution of services and lack of consistency.
